channel.title: Top Headlines from World Press Review

image.title: Top Headlines from World Press Review

item.title: AirAsia: Battling for the Indonesian Market
item.description: The Malaysia and Thai markets have proved fruitful for AirAsia, but tough competition means Indonesia is proving a tougher nut to crack.

item.title: Indigenous Movements: Between Neoliberalism and Leftist Governments
item.description: After scoring resounding victories, indigenous movements of South America are encountering new challenges on institutional and state levels that they have not been able to answer.

item.title: Fiji Divided Along Race in May 2006 Elections
item.description: As Fijians went to the polls this month it was hoped that the island nation would move from runaway communalism to inter-communal bargaining and coalitions.

item.title: Exotic Orchids Face Extinction
item.description: Agricultural scientists are urging the Indian government to protect rare orchid species that are facing severe depletion due to deforestation and illegal smuggling.

item.title: Migration Act Change Is 'Heavy-Handed'
item.description: Dr. Graham Thom, refugee coordinator for Amnesty International Australia spoke with us about the concerns Amnesty has with the new migration laws.

item.title: Deby Wins Third Term as Opposition Cries Foul
item.description: According to figures released on Sunday, Deby received 77.6 percent of the vote, sealing his bid to extend his 15-year reign by another five years.

item.title: Political Newcomer Aims to Unify Opposition Party
item.description: It remains to be seen if Prof. Arthur Mutambara, one of Africas foremost scientists, can strengthen the main political party opposing President Robert Mugabe.

item.title: Europe Is Adamant On the Issue of El Masri
item.description: Ignore a problem long enough and it will go away. Or so hoped Macedonia. But Europe isn't buying it. Will the issue affect Macedonia's prospects for integration?

item.title: Former Rwanda Commander Joins New U.N. Committee
item.description: United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan has appointed Romeo Dallair to a new Advisory Committee on Genocide Prevention.

item.title: Paul Themba Nyathi
item.description: Legislation that allows the ruling ZANU-PF to ban "traitors" from traveling in or out of Zimbabwe is part of an ongoing effort to entrench President Mugabe's hold on power.

item.title: Zuma Trial Heightens Rape Awareness
item.description: One of South Africa's most celebrated musicians added her voice to the chorus lamenting the government's failure to tackle the country's tragic rape problem.

item.title: Canadian Natives Fight Grave Odds
item.description: The litany of abuse of these Canadian Natives has been going on for hundreds of years.

item.title: Dominican Immigrants Face Challenges in New York City Public Schools
item.description: As the largest exporter of immigrants to New York City, the Dominican Republic is represented by approximately 10 percent of the 1.1 million students within the New York City public school system.

item.title: Mexico: Oil Depletion and Illegal U.S. Immigration
item.description: The international press examines Mexicos declining oil production and what it might mean for the U.S. debate on illegal immigration.

item.title: India's Top-Ranking B-Schools Are at a Crossroads
item.description: So far, the top-ranking B-schools in India have failed to appear in the world's top 100 when compared to schools on a global scale. To do so, they must face some critical issues — and soon.

item.title: Maoists Ready for Peace Talks
item.description: Maoist insurgents, who have been waging an armed rebellion in Nepal for the last 10 years, announced last week that they were now ready for peace talks with the newly-formed democratic government.

item.title: Fiji Goes to the Poll
item.description: Voters on Fiji's 320-odd islands go to the polls on Saturday in an eight-day general election despite the political uncertainty that remains over the South Pacific nation's future.

item.title: Afghan Hijackers Aid Call for Asylum Work Rights
item.description: Nine Afghan men who fled Afghanistan six years ago by hijacking a plane have added their voices to calls on the government to allow asylum seekers to work.

item.title: The Young and the Old: Radical Islam Takes Root in the Balkans
item.description: Wahhabism, a fundamentalist form of Islam prevalent in Saudi Arabia, has been actively promoted within the region's Islamic communities over the past 15 years.

item.title: Britain Undermining Rights of Foreign Prisoners
item.description: The Prison Reform Trust and other organizations suggest that the British government is fueling xenophobia and systematically violating the rights of foreign nationals being held in its prisons.

item.title: Rescuing Cairo's Lost Heritage
item.description: As Egypt's stock of locally trained conservation specialists grows, so too does the number of conservation projects in historic Cairo, one of the world's oldest Islamic cities.

item.title: Islamic Dress Code to be Strictly Enforced
item.description: Conservative hardliners are cracking down on non-compliance with the Islamic dress code for women.

item.title: Iran's Oil Bourse: A Threat to the U.S. Economy?
item.description: While Iran's putative nuclear program has become a major focus of the international media, there are many who strongly believe that the program is only a cover for the U.S. government's true motive in a possible attack against Iran.
